Ah, what can ail thee, wretched wight,</br>Alone and palely loitering;</br>The sedge is wither'd from the lake,</br>And no birds sing.
Ah, what can ail thee, wretched wight,</br>So haggard and so woe-begone?</br>The squirrel's granary is full,</br>And the harvest's done.
I see a lilly on thy brow,</br>With anguish moist and fever dew;</br>And on thy cheek a fading rose</br>Fast withereth too.
I met a lady in the meads</br>Full beautiful, a faery's child;</br>Her hair was long, her foot was light,</br>And her eyes were wild.
I set her on my pacing steed,</br>And nothing else saw all day long;</br>For sideways would she lean, and sing</br>A faery's song.
I made a garland for her head,</br>And bracelets too, and fragrant zone;</br>She look'd at me as she did love,</br>And made sweet moan.
She found me roots of relish sweet,</br>And honey wild, and manna dew;</br>And sure in language strange she said,</br>I love thee true.
She took me to her elfin grot,</br>And there she gaz'd and sighed deep,</br>And there I shut her wild sad eyes—</br>So kiss'd to sleep.
And there we slumber'd on the moss</br>And there I dream'd, ah woe betide,</br>The latest dream I ever dream'd</br>On the cold hill side.
I saw pale kings, and princes too,</br>Pale warriors, death-pale were they all;</br>Who cry'd — "La belle Dame sans merci</br>Hath thee in thrall!"
I saw their starv'd lips in the gloam</br>With horrid warning gaped wide,</br>And I awoke, and found me here</br>On the cold hill side.
And this is why I sojourn here</br>Alone and palely loitering</br>Though the sedge is wither'd from the lake,</br>And no birds sing.</br>
